sn44.2:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn44.2:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Anurādha was staying not far from the Buddha in a wilderness hut.
sn44.2:4.3: Then several wanderers who follow other paths went up to Venerable Anurādha
sn44.2:4.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side
sn44.2:4.7: “Reverend Anurādha, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them in these four ways:
sn44.2:4.8: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.”
sn44.2:4.9: “Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
sn44.2:4.10: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.”
sn44.2:4.11: When he said this, the wanderers said to him:
sn44.2:4.12: “This mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.”
sn44.2:4.13: Then, after rebuking Venerable Anurādha by calling him “junior” and “foolish”, the wanderers got up from their seat and left.
sn44.2:5.1: Soon after they had left, Anurādha thought:
sn44.2:5.2: “If those wanderers were to inquire further, how should I answer them so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should I explain in line with his teaching, so that there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”
sn44.2:5.3: Then Venerable Anurādha went up to the Buddha,
sn44.2:5.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn44.2:5.5: and told him what had happened.

sn44.2:10.1: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn44.2:10.2: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn44.2:18.1: “So, Anurādha, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn44.2:18.5: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn44.2:18.6: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn44.2:18.7: Being fed up, they lose interest.
sn44.2:18.9: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn44.2:18.10: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
sn44.2:19.1: What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as form?”
sn44.2:19.3: “Do you regard the Realized One as feeling …
sn44.2:19.11: “What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as in form?”
sn44.2:19.13: “Or do you regard the Realized One as distinct from form?”
sn44.2:19.15: “Do you regard the Realized One as in feeling …
sn44.2:20.1: “What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as possessing form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn44.2:20.3: “What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as one who is without form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn44.2:20.5: “In that case, Anurādha, since you don’t acknowledge the Realized One as a genuine fact in the present life, is it appropriate to declare:
sn44.2:20.6: ‘Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
sn44.2:20.7: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist’?”
sn44.2:20.11: In the past, as today, all I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering.”
